hints.content: Start by understanding the relationship between the indices of the string and the digits. Each index `i` corresponds to the digit `num[i]`, which tells you how many times the digit `i` should appear in the string.
Consider creating a frequency array or dictionary to count how many times each digit appears in the string. This will help you compare the expected counts with the actual counts.
Remember that the digits in the string range from '0' to '9'. Since the maximum length of the string is 10, you only need to count occurrences for digits 0 through 9.
Think about how you will handle the counting. You can iterate through the string and increment the count for the digit represented by each character.
After counting the occurrences, you need to verify for each index `i` whether the digit `i` occurs `num[i]` times. This requires a loop to check each index against the counts you've collected.
Be cautious about the indices. If `num[i]` is greater than the length of the string, you can immediately return false, since a digit cannot appear more times than there are total digits.
Consider edge cases, such as when the string contains only one digit or when all digits are the same. How would your logic handle such cases?
Make sure to convert the characters in `num` to integers when comparing counts. For example, `int(num[i])` will give you the integer value of the character at index `i`.
As you implement the comparison, remember that if any index fails the condition, you should return false immediately. You don't need to check the remaining indices once you find a mismatch.
Finally, ensure that your function returns true only if all conditions are satisfied for every index. A simple boolean variable can help track whether all checks pass.

questionNotes: The input string 'num' consists of digits only.
The length of 'num' is between 1 and 10.
Each index i corresponds to the digit i, and num[i] indicates how many times digit i should occur.
Return true if all conditions are satisfied, otherwise return false.
